title: Frequency and period - series and parallel springs

content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="M sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> is suspended vertically from two identical springs of negligible mass, spring constant <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and unstretched length <math alttext="L sub U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub></math>, as shown in the figures. In Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, one spring is attached to the end of the other spring. The block is then attached to the end of the bottom spring and set into vertical oscillation of period <math alttext="T sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. In Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the springs are hung side by side. The block is attached to the bottom ends of both springs and again set into vertical oscillation of period <math alttext="T sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="the fraction T sub 2 over T sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
